name: Argyll and Bute Council
systems: Sentiment Metrics social media sentiment analysis
notes: It appears the social media sentiment analysis is a part of a system (ContactCentre 59R ACD) which groups together different streams individual may use to contact an organisation, including social media. The sentiment analysis portion is provided by Sentiment Metrics, who are now called Sentiment. - http://www.monitoring-social-media.com/sentiment-metrics-undergoes-rebrand-and-launches-sentiment
extract: "We use the Sentiment Metrics social media service which uses algorithms to determine user sentiment about the council based on customer social media postings. ... Both Sentiment metrics and the voice auto service form part of a wider customer engagement solution contract with Softcat PLC who subcontracted Oracle and Netcall for the relevant elements " [More details within the FOI response]

name: Birmingham City Council
notes: A popular business intelligence package, sold by SAP. Has a wide array of possible functions, including analytical capacities. Marketing copy extract: "Enable all business users to understand trends and root causes with easy-to-use BI tools for ad hoc queries, reporting, and analysis in a Web environment. ... Build impactful BI visualization, dashboards, and analytics applications to assess risk, improve efficiencies, highlight unique insights, and identify opportunities." - https://www.sap.com/products/bi-platform.html

name: Birmingham City Council
notes: A popular, versatile "visual analytics" platform. - https://www.tableau.com/

name: Blaby District Council
notes: This popular piece of "geodemographic segmentation" software is used to gain insights into different populations of people, down to the level of neighbourhood (postcode) and household. See page 83 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for a closer look at Mosaic: https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: Bournemouth Borough Council use AccsMap alongside a number of other applications to attempt to understand traffic flows. From AccsMap's marketing copy: "AccsMap is a map-based road casualty analysis system developed  specifically for the UK. It is a comprehensive input, reporting, analysis and validation system for road accidents, enabling data to be viewed and interrogated on a map background." - http://www.buchanancomputing.net/accsmap.html
extract: "AccsMap is used to organise and analyse road casualty data."

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: Arcady is used to model roundabouts. More information: https://trlsoftware.com/products/junction-signal-design/junctions/arcady/

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: An urban traffic management and control system which uses "data analysis and auto-adaptive management of traffic light networks". - https://www.indracompany.com/en/control-systems
extract: "We use Urban Traffic Management and Control (UTMC) systems such as Scoot, Mova and Stratos to assess traffic flows and automatically adjust traffic signals to optimise traffic flow and help reduce congestion."

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: A fairly old urban traffic control system, in use since at least the 90s, which utilises sensors to optimise traffic flows with traffic signals. - http://www.ukroads.org/webfiles/tal04-95.pdf

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: A customer experience system, now called Orlo. Orlo carries out a degree of sentiment analysis, although it is unclear if Bournemouth Borough Council use this aspect of the system[1]. The system also has some social media monitoring capabilities[2]. - [1] https://orlo.tech/our-ecosystem/social-customer-care/  [2] https://orlo.tech/our-ecosystem/media-monitoring/

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: A Siemens produced traffic management system with a wide array of capabilities, including the processing of real-time sensor information. Processing is carried out on Siemens' servers. - https://www.siemens.co.uk/traffic/en/index/productssolutionsservices/systems/traffic-management-system-stratos.htm

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: A popular, versatile "visual analytics" platform. - https://www.tableau.com/
extract: "The Insight, Policy and Performance Team have just started to use Tableau for data visualisation. Our tableau dashboards can be seen here: https://public.tableau.com/profile/bcpinsight#!/ "

name: City of Bradford Metropolitan District Council
notes: A system used for data linkage, with the aim of analytics being performed upon the linked data. Bradford City Council use the system for schools allocation based on a number of factors. CapitaONE is produced by the public sector outsourcing giant, Capita. Capita market the system as allowing local authorities to see the "full picture" of their citizens and facilitating effective interventions[1]. See page 99 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more on Capita[2].  [1] https://www.capita-one.co.uk/about-us  [2] https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "CapitaONE - schools allocation based on parents selection and other criteria such as distance etc"

name: City of Bradford Metropolitan District Council
notes: The LCS is a system, provided by LiquidLogic, developed to support "all aspects of social work with children", including case management and record keeping. It attempts to unify record keeping and can assist the social worker user in making connections within a case. From LiquidLogic's marketing copy: "Not simply an electronic social care record, the system can assist practitioners’ professional judgement by helping to make connections within a case, which may not otherwise be so apparent. ... the system reacts dynamically to information it is given."[1] The Early Help Module "is a complete solution designed to act as a general case management tool for children outside of Social Care", also provided by LiquidLogic [2] It is commonly used in conjunction with the LCS, including by Bradford City Council in this example.  [1] https://www.liquidlogic.co.uk/children/liquidlogic-childrens-system-lcs/  [2] https://www.liquidlogic.co.uk/children/early-help-module-ehm/
extract: "LCS (including Early Help) - child assessments and service levels determined by input of assessment info"

name: London Borough of Brent
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "The Benefit Service uses Risk Based Verification (RBV) software in the processing of new claims (NC) and changes in circumstances (CIC) relating to Housing Benefit and Council Tax Support claims. Claimants make new claims and report changes via online electronic forms, and having provided the required information about their family circumstances, a RBV “score” is generated via referral to a third party web-based RBV product. The RBV software uses a propensity model based on national data relating to the relative likelihood, or “risk”, of the claimant’s claim being susceptible to fraud or error. The NC or CIC is thus risk-scored and differing levels of evidence are required, depending on the risk score, to support the claim; the higher the risk scoring, the greater the evidence requirement before the claim is processed."

name: Brighton and Hove City Council
notes: In a strategy paper attached to their Freedom of Information request response, Brighton and Hove City Council their intention to use use predictive analytics, either in the present or future.
extract: "a centralised performance management system (aggregated statistics on operational business areas / trends) which we use to provide an evidence base for decisions about resources, funding or service delivery" From 'Data Insight Strategy Paper', attached to the FOI response: "These are capabilities that allow us to extract insight from data in innovative ways, allowing us to use historical data to predict the future, model alternative scenarios, test out policies virtually. These can be supervised by an analyst or be unsupervised (using machine learning). The potential benefits are significant but it requires specialist tools and expertise to ensure the outputs are meaningful."

name: Brighton and Hove City Council
notes: In a presentation attached to the Freedom of Information request response, B&HCC name ArcGIS under "mapping" and "network analysis" on a slide detailing their "Data Insight Strategy analytics toolkit". Esri, who produce ArcGIS, claim, among other things, that the system can "Analyze patters to make predictions and determine next steps". - https://www.esri.com/en-us/arcgis/products/arcgis-online/capabilities/analyze-data

name: Brighton and Hove City Council
notes: A popular business intelligence package, sold by SAP. Has a wide array of possible functions, including analytical capacities. Marketing copy extract: "Enable all business users to understand trends and root causes with easy-to-use BI tools for ad hoc queries, reporting, and analysis in a Web environment. ... Build impactful BI visualization, dashboards, and analytics applications to assess risk, improve efficiencies, highlight unique insights, and identify opportunities." - https://www.sap.com/products/bi-platform.html
extract: "Currently, our primary BI platform is Business Objects. We are piloting dashboard tools like Tableau and Power BI. We may also use Excel or infographic tools, depending on requirements."

name: Brighton and Hove City Council
notes: This reference within the Freedom of Information response perhaps refers to an instance of SAP's Business Objects. A comment on the FOI response indicates this predictive analytics system is possibly being used for "Access Point analytics", although it is unclear what this refers to.
extract: B&HCC wrote in the main body of their FOI response: "BHCC is not using any data analytics, predictive analytics or algorithmic automated systems" However, the Word document contained a perhaps mistakenly included comment on this line which reads: "What about SAP Predictive Analytics? What tool is [an employee] going to be using for the Access Point analytics?"

name: Bristol City Council
notes: Related to Bristol's Integrated Analytical Hub

name: Carlisle City Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. See pages 99-100 for more information on Capita - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "We use the CAPITA Housing Benefit system in-conjunction with the Xantura P3.RBV web based software application for Risk Based Verification. The process risk scores claims using an algorithm to determine the level and extent of verification required for housing benefit claim assessment. The functionality is built into the software and decision making is taken manually by the Assessment Officers and is not an automated process. As this is to determine irregularities to reduce and deter fraudulent activity, a Private report was produced for Audit Committee but is not a public document for sharing in response to the request."

name: Carlisle City Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. See pages 55-65 and 95-96 for more information on Xantura - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "We use the CAPITA Housing Benefit system in-conjunction with the Xantura P3.RBV web based software application for Risk Based Verification. The process risk scores claims using an algorithm to determine the level and extent of verification required for housing benefit claim assessment. The functionality is built into the software and decision making is taken manually by the Assessment Officers and is not an automated process. As this is to determine irregularities to reduce and deter fraudulent activity, a Private report was produced for Audit Committee but is not a public document for sharing in response to the request."

name: Ceredigion County Council
notes: Daffodil is a system developed by the Institute of Public Care (IPC) for the Welsh Assembly Government which uses data from a variety of sources to attempt to project future need for care services in Wales. From the copy on the Daffodil website: "Daffodil pulls together in one place the information you need to plan what care services might be required in your local area in the future. Information from research and population projections show potential need for care over the next 20 years for children, adults and older people." - http://www.daffodilcymru.org.uk/
extract: "We do not use the sort predictive analytics techniques outlined within the Authority.  We do use prevalence data for certain conditions to estimate future demand for, say, social care using our own service data, population numbers and rates from Daffodil  [1]http://www.daffodilcymru.org.uk/ "

name: Ceredigion County Council
notes: As part of Ceredigion Council's Local Development Plan they project housing need. For more information on the LDP, see https://www.ceredigion.gov.uk/resident/planning-building-control-and-sustainable-drainage-body-sab/planning-building-control/ceredigion-local-development-plan-housing-figures/
extract: "In producing the LDP, we have used consultants to produce projected housing need by tenure, retail capacity studies, etc.  and we may do so again in the upcoming LDP review, but nothing is decided as yet."

name: Ceredigion County Council
notes: From Edge Analytics website: "POPGROUP is a suite of demographic software developed to generate population, household, labour force and other derived projections for specified geographical areas and/or population groups." - http://www.edgeanalytics.co.uk/popgroup.php
extract: "... and we use trend-based data to look at population projections in the cohort-based POPGROUP software"

name: Charnwood Borough Council
notes: Following an acquisition in 2016, Abritas has been integrated into the services provided by Civica. - https://www.civica.com/en-gb/container---news-insights--events/abritas-fully-integrated-into-civica/
extract: "This is a weekly process that creates a shortlist of Housing Applications for empty properties ordered by application priority and application date. Officers use their own judgement to accept, reject or override the ordered list, depending on individual applicants’ requirements."

name: Charnwood Borough Council
notes: It appears the system being referred to is a Housing Management System provided by Aareaon. It is unclear if Charnwood Borough Council use all of the features of this system or just the rent arrears related features. - https://www.aareon.co.uk/Housing_Management/Aareon_QL.197476.html
extract: "This is a weekly process that suggests next actions for Rent Arrears cases based on account balances, payment agreements and recent payment history. Officers use their own judgement to accept, reject or override the suggestions."

name: Chiltern District Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf

name: City of York Council
extract: "a centralised performance management system (aggregated statistics on operational business areas / trends) which we use to provide an evidence base for decisions about resources, funding or service delivery ... We do have a centralised performance management system (aggregated statistics on operational business areas / trends) which we use to provide an evidence base for decisions about resources, funding or service delivery, plus a master data management system to improve data quality throughout the organisation"

name: Copeland Borough Council
extract: "...we do use the GIS (Geographical Information Systems).This software uses council-held spatial information in conjunction with the LLPG corporate address database to provide staff and service users with easier and quicker access to data, automated integration between back-office systems, with spatial functionality being utilised to provide enhanced information analysis and enable data sharing between departments."

name: London Borough of Croydon
notes: A popular business intelligence package, sold by SAP. Has a wide array of possible functions, including analytical capacities. Marketing copy extract: "Enable all business users to understand trends and root causes with easy-to-use BI tools for ad hoc queries, reporting, and analysis in a Web environment. ... Build impactful BI visualization, dashboards, and analytics applications to assess risk, improve efficiencies, highlight unique insights, and identify opportunities." - https://www.sap.com/products/bi-platform.html

name: Dacorum Borough Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. See pages 97-98 for more information on CallCredit - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "Callcredit’s RBV algorithms were modelled using data received from Local Authorities relating to individuals’ applications for housing benefit (“HB”) and/or council tax reduction (“CTR”) (known as the Single Housing Benefit Extract or “SHBE”). Some of the SHBE data fields indicated where the claims verification process had identified incorrect information in HB/CTR applications.  Those fields were used to identify variables that were predictive of incorrect information and therefore a likely risk of error/fraud by the claimant. The models take input data from the Local Authority’s SHBE and attribute a risk score of 1-12, based on the predictive variables. The risk score is returned to the Local Authority client: a score of 1-3 refers to a ‘high’ risk of fraud/error; 4-8 is ‘medium’ risk; and 9-12 is ‘low’ risk."

name: Derbyshire Dales District Council
notes: Software offered by Northgate Public Services. Derbyshire Dales District Council say this system calculates risk scores.
extract: "In terms of undertaking risk assessments for Food Safety, Health & Safety, Environmental Permitting and Private Sector Housing Environmental Health use M3PP, which calculates risk scores."

name: Dudley Metropolitan Borough Council
extract: "Analysis of activity and potential future demand for Complex and Inclusion service"

name: Dudley Metropolitan Borough Council
extract: "Analysis of methods for identifying people at risk of loneliness and isolation - to be presented at Public Health England annal conference"

name: Dudley Metropolitan Borough Council
extract: "Health protection and surveillance: The team analyses data relating to air quality, immunisations, winter surveillance and infection control, in order to guide these preventative programmes."

Build impactful BI visualization, dashboards, and analytics applications to assess risk, improve efficiencies, highlight unique insights, and identify opportunities." - https://www.sap.com/products/bi-platform.html

name: Dudley Metropolitan Borough Council
systems: Single Person Discount Review (TransUnion/CallCredit) -- provided by external service provider, Civica
notes: It appears Dudley Council used a system developed by TransUnion (formerly CallCredit) to attempt to detect when an individually has been wrongly claiming a Single Person Council Tax Discount. (Full council tax bills assume a property is the main home of two adults. If the property is the main home of only one adult, the bill, after an application to the Council, can be reduced by 25%).
extract: "Single Person Discount Review – Information provided by TransUnion (formerly Call Credit) is used by our current external service provider (Civica ...) to assist with the verification of single person discount entitlement. ... [T]he information does not award or decline a claim."

name: London Borough of Ealing
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "Coactiva provide Risk Based Verification software in relation to Ealing Councils benefit services such as Housing and Council Tax by targeting claims that may be deemed to be of a higher risk of fraud and/or errors."

name: East Hampshire District Council
notes: Microsoft Dynamics is a popular business intelligence system with a wide number of possible applications. It has the capacity to perform complex data analytics. - https://dynamics.microsoft.com/en-us/
extract: "Predictive outputs are produced using commercial software, who’s outputs are used only internally as a commercial licence exists limiting the ability to share this information with external commercial organisation. ... The profile data (geodemographics) is also populated in to our Microsoft dynamics application, enabling use to analyse the data (Cases) by mosaic types."

name: East Hampshire District Council
notes: Experian Public Sector Profiler maybe refers to Experian Mosaic, a popular piece of "geodemographic segmentation" software is used to gain insights into different populations of people, down to the level of neighbourhood (postcode) and household. See page 83 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for a closer look at Mosaic: https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "Predictive outputs are produced using commercial software, who’s outputs are used only internally as a commercial licence exists limiting the ability to share this information with external commercial organisation. The tools used postcode information (copyright the Royal Mail) to profile properties and larger geographic areas. ... The profile data (geodemographics) is also populated in to our Microsoft dynamics application, enabling use to analyse the data (Cases) by mosaic types."

name: East Riding of Yorkshire Council
systems: Risk Based Verification (Xantura & Northgate PS Ltd)
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. See pages 55-65 and 95-96 for more information on Xantura - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "For the assessment of Housing Benefit and Council Tax support claims we use Risk Based Verification. This uses algorithms to identify the level of potential fraud and error for each claim and are classified high, medium or low risk which in turn allows the assessor to determine the level of ‘proofs’ required to accompany the claim. The software is from a company called Xantura who work with Northgate PS Ltd who are our software supplier for the revenues and benefit services."

name: Erewash Borough Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "The only department that use anything like this is the Risk Based Verification system that Council Tax and Housing Benefits use to classify claims in order to speed up processing of low risk claims."

name: Folkestone & Hythe District Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. See pages 55-65 and 95-96 for more information on Xantura - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "The only software that Folkestone & Hythe District Council operate that uses algorithms is Xantura. This is used to return the "risk score" of a benefit claim and which determines the level of supporting evidence required. This software was delivered as part of a software solution by external consultants who use Xantura so there are no specific reports, briefing notes, assessments etc or form of paper trail. There are no training manuals or material as little training is required as all that is received is an onscreen message stating what is required."

name: Fylde Borough Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. See pages 97-98 for more information on CallCredit - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "Your request was referred to the Council's Benefits' Team who, in turn, liaised with the software provider. Consequently, taking into account the comments of TransUnion's (formerly Callcredit's) Legal Team, the Council considers that it must refuse to disclose information relating to the software used to process claims for housing benefit and council tax reduction. We can confirm the Council uses Risk Based Verification application software to aid an administrative process of gathering evidence in support of a claim for Housing Benefit and/or Council Tax Reduction. The information, procedures etc. however are considered sensitive as they form part of the Council's Fraud and Error Strategy and are not to be disclosed into the public domain."

name: Greater Manchester Combined Authority
extract: "a number of CadCorp tools ... [T]he following systems are used by the Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) ... As part of risk modelling our Data Analysts utilise a number of CadCorp tools to assist with predicting appliance response times"

name: Hertfordshire County Council
extract: "We also profile to identify people who might be interested in supporting our work in specialised areas (for example, as foster carers or adoptive parents) We might also use profile data to identify people who would most benefit from a targeted service."

name: Hertfordshire County Council
extract: "We analyse our existing service data to make sure we can provide the services needed in the future ... Sometimes we may compare or combine this data with population data from other sources, official data from Office for National Statistics, NHS Digital or  commercial sources. We don't use this to identify individuals – only to forecast future demand (for example, demand for school places, social care and health trends."

name: Hertfordshire County Council
notes: This popular piece of "geodemographic segmentation" software is used to gain insights into different populations of people, down to the level of neighbourhood (postcode) and household. See page 83 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for a closer look at Mosaic: https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "We do use general profiling tool (Currently Experian Mosaic)to understand the needs and make-up of the Hertfordshire population, analysis is done on geographic areas, because we are interested in the service demands across communities rather than profiling individual residents."

name: Hull City Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "The only department of the Council which uses automated decision making is the Housing Benefit. New claims for Housing Benefit are assessed using a system of Risk Based Verification. The system uses algorithms to categorise claims into low, medium or high risk, to advise the assessor on the levels of evidence that can be requested. Ultimately, the decision as to what evidence is required is that of the person assessing the claim, and Risk Based Verification is only used to inform the process."

name: Huntingdonshire District Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. See pages 97-98 for more information on CallCredit - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "We do use risk based verification software which provides a “risk score” of low, medium and high. This is a product called CallCredit within our case management system Northgate which is used by Revenues teams. There is no documentation on how risk scores are applied; it’s based on the individual circumstances of each claim."

name: Inverclyde Council
systems: Scottish Patients at Risk of Readmission and Admission (SPARRA) (Health & Social Care Partnership)
notes: From ISD Scotland website: "Scottish Patients at Risk of Readmission and Admission is a risk prediction tool developed by ISD which predicts an individual's risk of being admitted to hospital as an emergency inpatient within the next year. ... Scores are calculated for approximately 4.2  million patients.  Information on those whose score indicates that they may be  at  increased risk of emergency admission are accessed by authorised health care  professionals in NHS Boards, CHPs and GP practices. SPARRA scores can  range from 1 to 99% for patients in the cohort. Patients with a score of 50%,  for example, are generally said to have a 1 in 2 chance of being admitted to  hospital in the prediction year." - https://www.isdscotland.org/Health-Topics/Health-and-Social-Community-Care/SPARRA/

name: Ipswich Borough Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. See pages 97-98 for more information on CallCredit - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "The only system currently in use that we think meets your criteria is the Risk-based-verification software used to pre-process Housing Benefit claims. However, as this process is outsourced and its functions are run as a service, we have no data concerning the particular hardware or software which may be used."

name: London Borough of Islington
extract: "Islington has procured a data matching tool that creates a “golden record” for each person in Islington. The system is called Holistix and is provided by a company called Quality Education Systems (QES). The attached slide sets provide an overview of the system, the types of data included and the purposes for which it is used. The council has a Using Data Better programme with a core aim of establishing a council-wide linked dataset that can be used for both operational purposes (where there is a legal basis to share data in this way such as identifying fraud, identifying children for REACH programme). Additionally, we use a de-personalised extract of this dataset for strategic purposes. This includes for example, to better understand the needs of council tenants and households to inform a new model of service delivery to better meet residents’ needs, utilise council resource more efficiently, and improve outcomes."

name: Kent County Council
notes: Acorn is a geodemographic segmentation system which aims to provide insights into where different demographics of people are living, originally used in marketing. From CACI's marketing copy on Acorn: "Acorn is a powerful consumer classification that segments the UK population. By analysing demographic data, social factors, population and consumer behaviour, it provides precise information and an understanding of different types of people."[1] For a look at a similar system, Experian's Mosaic, and a look at the history of geodemographics, please refer to pages 83-94 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance".[2] For more information on the Kent Integrated Dataset, the system Kent County Council use Acorn as part of, please refer to this lecture delivered by Kent County Council's Head of Health Intelligence[3] and pages 37-47 of the Data Justice Lab's report.[2]   [1] https://acorn.caci.co.uk/  [2] https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf  [3] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zgNowZ_UJAg
extract: "The Kent Integrated Dataset includes population segmentation data items from two proprietary systems: CACI ACORN and Experian Mosiac."

name: Kent County Council
notes: The Kent Integrated Dataset is a combined dataset used for population health planning. For more information on this system, please refer to the Data Justice Lab's case study in their report, "Data Scores as Governance" (pp. 36-47). - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf

name: Kent County Council
notes: Mosaic is a geodemographic segmentation system which aims to provide insights into where different demographics of people are living, originally used in marketing. For a closer look at this system and the history of geodemographics, refer to pages 83-94 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance".[1] For more information on the Kent Integrated Dataset, the system which Mosaic is used as part of, please refer to this lecture delivered by Kent County Council's Head of Health Intelligence[2] and pages 37-47 of the Data Justice Lab's report.[1]  [1] https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf  [2] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zgNowZ_UJAg
extract: "The Kent Integrated Dataset includes population segmentation data items from two proprietary systems: CACI ACORN and Experian Mosiac."

name: Leeds City Council
notes: FFT Aspire is system which Leeds City Council say is used to predict students' future performance and set future attainment targets in schools in the Leeds area.
extract: "The online system, FFT Aspire, is used by over 13,600 schools, LAs, MATs and chains in England and Wales.  Part is backwards looking with an analysis of pupil results and pupil progress that provides school leaders with insightful data to support school improvement and self-evaluation.  It also includes estimates of future performance built up from pupil level.  These are used by teachers to inform the setting of ambitious and aspirational targets for students."

name: Liverpool City Council
extract: "we share our data ... with the CCG in a psuedonymised format at client level to facilitate primary care risk stratification based on the "Welsh model" for large scale health risk identification"

name: London Borough of Southwark
systems: Student council tax discount review, with National Fraud Authority Initiative & Fujitsu
notes: From a Fujitsu authored article on the system: "Fujitsu’s solution establishes a fraud screen which can identify the claims that are most likely to be fraudulent or erroneous. The system automatically correlates known facts about each individual such as the distance between their home postcode and the university; the length and subject of the course being studied, as well as other available lifestyle data. The fraud screen then streams the data through an analytics processing engine and a range of analytic algorithms to help predict which claims are bogus." - https://www.fujitsu.com/fts/about/resources/case-studies/fs_southwark-council.html
extract: "As part of an NFA initiative Southwark Council entered into a data matching exercise to evaluate the student discounts awarded for Council tax purposes. The review was a new pilot developed for free with National Fraud Authority (NFA) and Fujitsu. There was no sharing of the methodology or software. The data analytics were conducted between NFA and Fujitsu. The results were shared with our Revenue & Benefits and Council Tax teams."

name: Medway Council
notes: "The National Child Measurement Programme (NCMP) measures the height and weight of children in Reception class (aged 4 to 5) and year 6 (aged 10 to 11), to assess overweight and obesity levels in children within primary schools. ... The data can be used nationally to support local public health  initiatives, and locally to inform the planning and delivery of services for children. ... The programme was set up in line with the government's strategy to tackle obesity, and to: - inform local planning and delivery of services for children, - gather population-level data to allow analysis of trends in growth patterns and obesity" - https://digital.nhs.uk/services/national-child-measurement-programme/

name: Medway Council
extract: "involves use of a nationally approved algorithm to calculate a person's risk of cardiovascular event in the next 10 years"

name: Milton Keynes Council
extract: "For adults in England aged 40-74 without a pre-existing condition, it checks your circulatory and vascular health and what your risk of getting a disabling vascular disease is. You will be invited once every five years under this programme, unless you are identified as high risk or have one of the conditions (next slide) then you will be reviewed annually by your GP. Cardiovascular disease covers many diseases."

name: Northamptonshire County Council
notes: A leaflet provided by Capita on Capita One Admissions & Transfers lists as a key benefit of the system "Target interventions: Easily identify children who frequently change school, giving a clearer picture of a child's situation to shape interventions, if necessary." Also: "Plan for future school places: Your admissions data in One can be analysed useing One Analytics to understand trends and where to target future resources."
extract: "Capita One:Admissions–ranking developed by the supplier for school placements"

name: Northamptonshire County Council
notes: A complex system used for monitoring pupil progress, with the ability to forecast and be used to guide interventions. - https://fft.org.uk/
extract: "Fischer Family Trust Aspire–education tool for predictive analysis and pupil target setting(used by schools and the LA)."

name: Northamptonshire County Council
notes: More information from a fact sheet provided along with the Freedom of Information request response: "YOGRS is the youth justice system specific version of the Offender GroupReconviction Scale (OGRS).  OGRS estimates the probability that offenderswith a given history of offending will be resanctioned for any recordable offencewithin two years of sentence, or release if sentenced to custody.In the youthjustice system (YJS), the term sanction isused to refer to convictions and out ofcourt disposals (OOCD).Whilst the calculation cannot be defined as absolute for anindividualyoungperson, it provides a percentage calculation of reconvictionin comparison toasimilar cohort.The National Offender Management Service (NOMS)haveproducedthealgorithm and reference dataunderlyingOGRS, and haveverified it as suitablefor usein the YJS.The inclusion of YOGRS in the AssetPlus framework willhelp to promote greater alignment with OASys (NationalProbationService’sassessment framework), which will be of benefitforyoung peoplewho moveinto adult services."
extract: "Within the CareDirector system within the Youth Offending Service we have an assessment called AssetPlus which incorporates a system called YOGRS which estimates the probability that someone may re-offend."

name: Nottinghamshire County Council
notes: Mosaic is a geodemographic segmentation system which aims to provide insights into where different demographics of people are living, originally used in marketing. For a closer look at this system and the history of geodemographics, refer to pages 83-94 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance".[1] For more information on the Kent Integrated Dataset, the system which Mosaic is used as part of, please refer to this lecture delivered by Kent County Council's Head of Health Intelligence[2] and pages 37-47 of the Data Justice Lab's report.[1]  [1] https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf  [2] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zgNowZ_UJAg
extract: "population segmentation with MOSIAC [sic] data to understand spatial distribution of risk of alcohol harm"

name: Purbeck District Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. See pages 99-100 for more information on Capita - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "The Revenues and Benefits Partnership uses Xantura’s Risk BasedVerification (RBV) module which is embedded within the Capita Revenues andBenefits software. The RBV process is used for new housing benefit (HB)and council tax support (CTS) claims only – it is not used for HB/CTSchanges in circumstances."

name: Rotherham Metropolitan Borough Council
notes: From Mobysoft's website: "RentSense is a series of complex algorithms that analyse a housing organisation’s tenants’ transactional history, which is coupled with a predictive analytical application that then predicts which tenants will and won’t pay their rent. It then produces a list of tenants, in priority order, that need contacting that week regarding their rent." - https://www.mobysoft.com/products/rentsense

name: Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "The only service that use algorithmically systems are our Housing Benefitteam. They use a Risk Based Verification tool in order to inform decisionsabout the level of evidence required in support of a claim.  This is basedon algorithms. It is not an automated decision making piece of software asit merely provides a recommendation which then requires human interventionto accept or change."

name: South Bucks District Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "RBV isn't an automated decision affecting entitlement to benefit. It aids anadministrative process to gathering evidence in support of a claim. The result doesn'taccept or decline a claim."

name: Suffolk County Council
notes: The Connect Measure was introduced by Suffolk County Council aspart of an attempt to move towards preventative work, rather than costly reactive services, and to improve performance monitoring. According to a Nesta article, the Connect Measure is "a set of shared outcomes, which health and social care [can] work towards. Th[e] framework contains 35 measures relating to important outcomes, such as the number of emergency admissions, ambulance call-outs, length of stay in hospital and delayed transfers of care." The article continues, "Data integration means new preventative programmes can be evaluated better and support planning for further preventative work. ... Performance management is now based onmeaningful outcome measures such as wellbeing, rather than crude input or output measures." - https://www.nesta.org.uk/feature/eight-ways-councils-are-using-data-create-better-services/a-shared-outcomes-framework-for-health-and-social-care/
extract: "Connect measures are provided on a ‘live’ basis for social care via web-basedBusiness Intelligence reporting tools. These tools allow managers to ‘drill down’ from acounty overview of relevant social care Connect measures, to individual recording.This means that any practice issues can be worked on with the individual workerassigned to a specific case, and trends and key facts can be established around howthe system is working as a whole."

name: Sunderland City Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. See pages 97-98 for more information on CallCredit - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf

name: London Borough of Waltham Forest
notes: A data analytics platform. - https://looker.com/

name: London Borough of Waltham Forest
notes: A machine learning platform. - https://aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/

name: Weymouth and Portland Borough Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. See pages 99-100 for more information on Capita - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "We use Xantura’s Risk Based Verification (RBV) module which is embeddedwithin the Capita Revenues and Benefits software.  We use the RBV process for new housing benefit and council tax support claims only – it is not used for HB/CTS changes in circumstances.The module was an additional purchase under our contract with Capita Software Services – we are unable to disclose details of Capita’s contract."

name: Wigan Metropolitan Borough Council
notes: Wigan provided a link which led to a report covering their "risk stratification model", which attempts to identify at risk individuals and families and target preventative measures accordingly. - http://democracy.wigan.gov.uk/documents/s38737/Enc.%201%20for%20Risk%20Stratification.pdf?a=1

name: Worcester City Council
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. See pages 99-100 for more information on Capita - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "Worcester City Council Revenues and Benefits Service does not use systems of the type described in the FOI request but does use data provided by a third party software supplier for Risk Based Verification (RBV) of benefit claims.The Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) expects councils to use RBV when assessing new claims. Data provided by the claimant when they apply for benefit is analysed by the third party supplier and a risk score returned to the council.This score guides the council in deciding how much evidence to ask the claimant to provide to verify their claim. The aim of RBV is to speed up the processing of low risk claims so the customer can be paid benefit quickly and to identify high risk claims for further investigation tominimise the risk of error or fraud. The decision whether or not to pay benefit to a claimant is not based solely on the RBV score. The council does not have a contract with the third party supplier butreceives the service as part of its contract with the council’s software supplier which is Capita."

name: London Borough of Hackney
notes: Hackney working with Xantura and Ernst and Young to develop the system
extract: The system uses ‘a predictive risk model which brings together data from multiple agencies to identify children who are most at risk of neglect or abuse’. The system is designed to provide social workers with monthly risk profiles that amalgamate information about families identified as most in need of early intervention

name: London Borough of Tower Hamlets
extract: "Xantura’s Children’s Safeguarding Profile Model brings together data from multiple agencies to identify children who are most at risk of neglect or abuse, but were not previously known to the local authority.  Using this model, one LA has already identified over 300 additional Troubled Families in need of support."

name: London Borough of Newham
extract: "Xantura’s Children’s Safeguarding Profile Model brings together data from multiple agencies to identify children who are most at risk of neglect or abuse, but were not previously known to the local authority. Using this model, one LA has already identified over 300 additional Troubled Families in need of support."
